posts.name: Titus Casas
posts.cooked: I have heard mixed feedback about whether the Neo line or the Kraken series of brushless motors is better. I'm interested in knowing your experiences with these options, particularly regarding their performance, reliability, and ease of use (wiring and programming). Specifically, is the Neo line (550, Vortex, Basic Neo Brushless Motor) or the Kraken series (X60, X44) more suitable for FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) applications?

posts.name: Phong Nguyen
posts.cooked: Kraken are better because they come with an integrated motor controller, eliminating the need for an external one.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: NEO Vortex is thrown at them, equipped with an integrated yet swappable controller. To get a precise idea, specify which NEO you're referring to and your desired enhanced capabilities. Keep in mind that answers may differ based on individual considerations.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: They’re not very different. The Kraken is a more powerful motor, but only by a little bit. The NEO can be used with a wider variety of motor controllers.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Phong Nguyen
posts.cooked: We have 8 neo vortexes sitting in storage for no reason.

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: If you don’t need them, I know a team that would really want them.

posts.name: Phong Nguyen
posts.cooked: We are researching selling them, and we also have old falcons that we plan to dispose of.

posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked:
The AMB calculator features a motor curve generator allowing comparison of various motor types. Clicking the "DOCS" link in the upper right corner provides additional information, including underlying formulas.

Neos have generally performed well, though historically Kraken X60s have shown potential advantages under heavy loads due to higher sustained speeds and torque capabilities. However, their high-end torque demands may exceed breaker and current limits over extended periods. Both motor types are suitable for most applications, but in scenarios where torque capacity is critical, the choice depends on specific requirements rather than historical performance.

link_counts.title: Motor Curve Display - AMB Robotics Calculator

posts.name: Trevor Dayal (he/him)
posts.cooked: we used neo vorteces kraken and falcon on our robot this year and neo vorteces kraken and falcon on our robot last year. my opinion is that whatever parts you have are the ones you should use if you can afford it upgrading neo to vorteces is the cheapest way to improve your robot but i think the performance boost from kraken is exaggerated. when buying new motors kraken has good programming with ctc but vorteces are cheaper easier to fix and work well for most things.

From a reliability standpoint, I’ve noticed that some NEO 550 and Spark MAX controllers have failed our team, whereas neither Falcon nor Kraken have encountered such issues. However, our Kraken units have faced challenges this year, including direct coral hits and frequent stalling on our elevator system.

On a programming level, the TalonFX offers extensive documentation and support, which is a significant advantage over REV, where finding proper documentation was difficult. Utilizing CTRE’s motion magic to tune PID parameters made the process more efficient and allowed for greater configurability without requiring additional cables, which is a notable benefit.

In terms of performance, I believe switching to Kraken won’t propel your team to the top 10 rankings alone. While I’m open to using both, it’s essential to consider other factors beyond just hardware upgrades.

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: For Rev it’s definitely the motor controller that makes it usually not the motor as SPM broke multiple times when I was trying to set up everything (kept on needing to put it into recovery mode) and my main gripe with the motors and SPM is the stupid encoder cable and the CAN cable the encoder you can’t do much about but the CAN cable you can replace with the TTB one or just use Thrifty Novas honestly like everyone said use what you have and can buy the difference is mostly negligible to other more important improvements with your team.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: One note I will put in here for 550s is that from our experience, you must support both ends of the shaft, place a 30 amp breaker on it, and current-limit it to give it the best chance of survival. This year was the first year all of our 550s survived the entire season because we followed these guidelines.

Last year, our team used Neo 550 and Vortex motors. While the Neo 550s proved reliable, we encountered significant issues with the Vortex motors. We utilized them on our MK4i swerve modules, experiencing frequent failures (a total of four Vortex motors broke). Additionally, the Vortex motors were unreliable, with several burning out during prototyping due to excessive torque, and their sparks often ceased functioning. By the end of the 2024 season, only three Vortex motors and their sparks remained fully operational after purchasing 12 in total.

This year, we switched to the Kraken motors, which demonstrated superior reliability and performance. All Kraken motors functioned perfectly, and the entire setup with Phoenix Tuner X was much smoother compared to previous attempts. Moreover, the Kraken motors exhibited nearly the same maximum speed as the Neo and Vortex models but provided three times the torque, making them a clear upgrade choice.

Krakers are superior because CTRE’s code is just better. I love Rev’s physical products but their software is just frustrating to work with. Anecdotally, I have heard multiple teams talk about their Neo Vortex’s breaking, never hear that about Krakers.

Anecdotally, I have heard multiple teams talk about their Neo Vortex’s breaking, never hear that about Kraket’s. Starting in December 2024, the Neo Vortex manufacturing was changed from the front piece being cast to being CNC’d. Prior to that, some teams used the Vortex with SDS mk4i modules that cracked the front plate of the motor. My team used the same setup but didn’t have issues.

posts.name: Aaron Calkins
posts.cooked:
The text is:  
"The team's performance is nearly identical, making a switch between the two product lines unnecessary unless you're already within a specific ecosystem."

From an electrical standpoint, the Kraken's ability to attach and remove wires has been very beneficial. We can connect motors directly to the PDH without needing intermediate connections, minimizing potential failures due to bad cramps or loose connections. Kids find it easier to handle wires since they don't need to cut them too short or redo connections when changing tools like ferrules, Anderson powerpoles, or using bare stripped wire with Wago connectors. This offers significant flexibility. Additionally, if a motor or component fails, we can remove the affected wires right at the motor, facilitating efficient hot swaps.

posts.name: Emerson OHara
posts.cooked:
high end torque apparently supportable by the Kraken requires a lot of current... probably more than breakers and current limits would allow for more than a very short time.

somewhat true but i think it is good to note that stator current of the motor is only 1:1 with supply current minus some minor switching losses when commanded at full voltage output 100% duty cycle. using trapezoidal if you apply a supply current limit at say 60a the stator can still pull ~148a ~40% duty cycle at 0rpm and that will slowly drop as rpms ramp up.

in our experience the Kraken was way more effective than NEOs on mechanism acceleration and efficiency.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
A friend who I surf with frequently is always looking to get new surfboards. He performs well in his view by catching a wave and then considers purchasing a more aggressive, lighter board or swapping fins for a custom-designed pair. However, if he just utilized [a specific feature or improvement], he would enhance his surfing performance.  

From my perspective, his approach to selecting boards is based on whether his current gear is hindering his potential. Observing him surf suggests he has significant room for growth in terms of skill development, implying that a more capable board isn’t necessarily required. That’s a different viewpoint, though.  

To me, the surfboard serves as a tool for enjoyment. If my definition of fun evolves and the board can’t adapt, I’ll consider upgrading.  

Discussions about the best board often revolve around computational fluid dynamics, pros’ preferences, or other factors. Yet, for most surfers, the minute benefits one board offers over another aren’t worth the cost. What matters is functionality. As long as the board meets my needs, I remain satisfied.  

As for motors, a Kraken X60 surpasses a NEO/Vortex on paper due to its benefits and extreme performance capabilities. However, when not operating at extremes, choosing what’s affordable and readily available is key.

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked: To me, the CTRE-based controller is the separator. We've just found it much easier to achieve the performance we were aiming for with the TalonFX/TalonFXS instead of the sparkMax. As others have pointed out, the motors on paper are very similar, and now you can go with TalonFXS plus Neo.
